name: titanium dioxide production, sulfate process | titanium dioxide | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/8221/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of titanium dioxide using concentrated sulfuric acid. Titanium dioxide (TiO2) is available as a white powder. It is stable and nontoxic. Titanium dioxide exists in natural minerals (rutile).;This dataset is based on data published by the European Commission (2007).;References:;European Commission (2007) Reference Document on Best Available Techniques for the Manufacture of Large Volume Inorganic Chemicals - Solids and Others industry. Integrated Pollution Prevention and Control. European Commission, Institute for Prospective Technological Studies, Edificio Expo.

From reception of raw materials at the factory gate.

This activity ends with the production of titanium dioxide. The dataset includes all raw materials, energy use, infrastructure, process emissions and waste.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Reference year of the production volume.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The present inventory uses low concentration ore ilmenite. The presence of iron in ilmenite leads to the cogeneration of iron sulfate. The sulfate process consists of the following sequential stages ;1. raw material import and preparation. The ore is stored in covered silos to avoid drying in case it becomes wet. It is then ground using large ball mills to produce particles typically 40-60 um for efficient dissolution with concentrated sulfuric acid. The main emissions at this stage are dust. This is collected by discharging the gas through bag filters. ;2. Digestion: reporting by EU producers indicates operation in batches is commonly used. The ilmenite is mixed with highly concentrated sulfuric acid (80-95%) and this is necessary to digest the feedstock containing TiO2. A highly exothermic reaction is initated by the addition of a measured quantity of steam at around 140°C.  The equation is summarized as: FeTiO3 + 2H2SO4 = TiOSO4 + 2H2O + FeSO4   The off-gases contain small quantities of dust, sulfur dioxide and acid fumes, which are removed by scrubbing. The resulting solid cake is dissolved in water and acid recycled from subsequent washing step. The primary intermediate from the reaction is titanyl suphate (TiOSO4),;3. Reduction: the digester liquor is contacted with scrap iron. This process generates a small amount of H2, which is returned to the air.;4. Clarification and crystallization: titanyl sufate is recovered from the solution and neutralised with lime before going to landfill. This material can be also used as inert filler. The clarified solution is pumped to bacth cooler/crystalisers to remove the bulk of the iron sulfate as the solid heptahydrate 'copperas'. This is widely used in water treatment and other industries. The iron-depleted product liquor is concentrated in evaporators.;5. Hydrolysis (hydrate precipitation). The reaction is:;TiOSO4 + 2H2O = TiO(OH)2 + H2SO4 ;Precipitation of the hydrated TiO2 is achieved by boiling the liquor for some hours followed by cooling to 60°C. At this stage of the process, the spenc acid with a concentration of 20-25% H2SO4 and 10-15% soluble salts (mainly iron, aluminium and mangesium sulfates) arises and is either recycled or neutralised with lime to produce gypsum which is preferntially sold at local markets as a commercial product.;6. Calcination: The rotary kilns are directly fired with oil or gas. Scrubbing calciner gas treatment has been upgraded in the past in order to reduce SO2 emissions. SO2 is normally reduced to form sulfuric acid and then recycled in the process. ;7. Finishing. The resulting solid is cooled, milled, coated, washed, dried and micronised.;References:;European Commission (2007) Reference Document on Best Available Techniques for the Manufacture of Large Volume Inorganic Chemicals - Solids and Others industry. Integrated Pollution Prevention and Control. European Commission, Institute for Prospective Technological Studies, Edificio Expo.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: All ore input is reported as 'ilmenite' (although the input is a mix of ilmenite and TiO2-enriched slag), resulting in an underestimation of the actual impacts due to this production process.

exchanges.description: Titanium dioxide commonly appears in the form of a white powder. Titanium dioxide produced by the sulfate process is preferred for paper, ink, rubber and a variety of specialty applications.

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.
